item.content:encoded: arXiv:2503.21088v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: This paper presents the ZJUKLAB team's submission for SemEval-2025 Task 4: Unlearning Sensitive Content from Large Language Models. This task aims to selectively erase sensitive knowledge from large language models, avoiding both over-forgetting and under-forgetting issues. We propose an unlearning system that leverages Model Merging (specifically TIES-Merging), combining two specialized models into a more balanced unlearned model. Our system achieves competitive results, ranking second among 26 teams, with an online score of 0.944 for Task Aggregate and 0.487 for overall Aggregate. In this paper, we also conduct local experiments and perform a comprehensive analysis of the unlearning process, examining performance trajectories, loss dynamics, and weight perspectives, along with several supplementary experiments, to understand the effectiveness of our method. Furthermore, we analyze the shortcomings of our method and evaluation metrics, emphasizing that MIA scores and ROUGE-based metrics alone are insufficient to fully evaluate successful unlearning. Finally, we emphasize the need for more comprehensive evaluation methodologies and rethinking of unlearning objectives in future research. Code is available at https://github.com/zjunlp/unlearn/tree/main/semeval25.

item.title: Power-scaled Bayesian Inference with Score-based Generative Models
item.content:encoded: arXiv:2504.10807v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: We propose a score-based generative algorithm for sampling from power-scaled priors and likelihoods within the Bayesian inference framework. Our algorithm enables flexible control over prior-likelihood influence without requiring retraining for different power-scaling configurations. Specifically, we focus on synthesizing seismic velocity models conditioned on imaged seismic. Our method enables sensitivity analysis by sampling from intermediate power posteriors, allowing us to assess the relative influence of the prior and likelihood on samples of the posterior distribution. Through a comprehensive set of experiments, we evaluate the effects of varying the power parameter in different settings: applying it solely to the prior, to the likelihood of a Bayesian formulation, and to both simultaneously. The results show that increasing the power of the likelihood up to a certain threshold improves the fidelity of posterior samples to the conditioning data (e.g., seismic images), while decreasing the prior power promotes greater structural diversity among samples. Moreover, we find that moderate scaling of the likelihood leads to a reduced shot data residual, confirming its utility in posterior refinement.

item.title: Universal Representations for Classification-enhanced Lossy Compression
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: lossy compression, rate-distortion-perception function, rate-distortion-classification function, universal encoder, image compression Summary: In the field of lossy compression, traditional algorithms balance compression rate and reconstruction distortion. However, a recent framework, the rate-distortion-perception (RDP) function, considers perceptual quality in addition to the classical tradeoff. The rate-distortion-classification (RDC) function, introduced in a study, evaluates compression performance based on classification accuracy alongside distortion. This paper explores the concept of universal representations, where a single encoder is designed to achieve multiple decoding objectives across various distortion and classification constraints. Experimental results on the MNIST dataset show that a universal encoder performs almost as well as individually optimized encoders for perceptual image compression tasks. Yet, in the RDC setting, reusing an encoder optimized for a specific classification-distortion tradeoff results in a significant distortion penalty when used for alternative points.

Summary: In lossy compression, a new approach considers perceptual quality and classification accuracy alongside distortion. Universal encoders show promising results for image compression tasks, but caution is needed when reusing an encoder optimized for specific tradeoffs in the classification-distortion setting.
arXiv:2504.13191v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: In lossy compression, the classical tradeoff between compression rate and reconstruction distortion has traditionally guided algorithm design. However, Blau and Michaeli [5] introduced a generalized framework, known as the rate-distortion-perception (RDP) function, incorporating perceptual quality as an additional dimension of evaluation. More recently, the rate-distortion-classification (RDC) function was investigated in [19], evaluating compression performance by considering classification accuracy alongside distortion. In this paper, we explore universal representations, where a single encoder is developed to achieve multiple decoding objectives across various distortion and classification (or perception) constraints. This universality avoids retraining encoders for each specific operating point within these tradeoffs. Our experimental validation on the MNIST dataset indicates that a universal encoder incurs only minimal performance degradation compared to individually optimized encoders for perceptual image compression tasks, aligning with prior results from [23]. Nonetheless, we also identify that in the RDC setting, reusing an encoder optimized for one specific classification-distortion tradeoff leads to a significant distortion penalty when applied to alternative points.

item.title: Intelligent road crack detection and analysis based on improved YOLOv8
item.content:encoded:
<div> Keywords: pavement distress, pothole detection, deep learning, road crack detection, attention mechanisms
Summary: This paper introduces a novel intelligent road crack detection and analysis system using the YOLOv8 deep learning framework. By training on a dataset of 4029 images, a target segmentation model has been developed to accurately identify and segment crack regions on roads. The model analyzes these segmented regions to calculate the maximum and minimum widths of cracks and their precise locations. The incorporation of ECA and CBAM attention mechanisms has significantly improved the model's accuracy and efficiency in detecting road cracks. This system presents a more efficient and cost-effective solution for monitoring road maintenance and enhancing road safety. <div> arXiv:2504.13208v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: As urbanization speeds up and traffic flow increases, the issue of pavement distress is becoming increasingly pronounced, posing a severe threat to road safety and service life. Traditional methods of pothole detection rely on manual inspection, which is not only inefficient but also costly. This paper proposes an intelligent road crack detection and analysis system, based on the enhanced YOLOv8 deep learning framework. A target segmentation model has been developed through the training of 4029 images, capable of efficiently and accurately recognizing and segmenting crack regions in roads. The model also analyzes the segmented regions to precisely calculate the maximum and minimum widths of cracks and their exact locations. Experimental results indicate that the incorporation of ECA and CBAM attention mechanisms substantially enhances the model's detection accuracy and efficiency, offering a novel solution for road maintenance and safety monitoring.

item.title: Mirror: Multimodal Cognitive Reframing Therapy for Rolling with Resistance
item.content:encoded:
dataset, multimodal approach, synthetic dataset, Vision-Language Models, therapeutic alliance
Summary: This article presents a novel approach to integrating nonverbal cues into AI therapy to improve the management of client resistance in psychotherapy. By introducing the Multimodal Interactive Rolling with Resistance (Mirror) synthetic dataset, which combines client statements with corresponding facial images, the study trains Vision-Language Models (VLMs) to analyze facial cues, infer emotions, and generate empathetic responses. The results indicate that the Mirror dataset significantly enhances the AI therapist's ability to handle resistance, outperforming traditional text-based cognitive behavioral therapy models. This approach shows promise in improving the therapist's counseling skills and strengthening the therapeutic alliance, even in the face of client resistance.
arXiv:2504.13211v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent studies have explored the use of large language models (LLMs) in psychotherapy; however, text-based cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) models often struggle with client resistance, which can weaken therapeutic alliance. To address this, we propose a multimodal approach that incorporates nonverbal cues, allowing the AI therapist to better align its responses with the client's negative emotional state. Specifically, we introduce a new synthetic dataset, Multimodal Interactive Rolling with Resistance (Mirror), which is a novel synthetic dataset that pairs client statements with corresponding facial images. Using this dataset, we train baseline Vision-Language Models (VLMs) that can analyze facial cues, infer emotions, and generate empathetic responses to effectively manage resistance. They are then evaluated in terms of both the therapist's counseling skills and the strength of the therapeutic alliance in the presence of client resistance. Our results demonstrate that Mirror significantly enhances the AI therapist's ability to handle resistance, which outperforms existing text-based CBT approaches.

item.title: Wavelet-based Variational Autoencoders for High-Resolution Image Generation
item.content:encoded:
Variational Autoencoders, Wavelet-VAE, image generation, high-resolution details, generative modeling
Summary: Wavelet-VAE is introduced as a novel approach to improve image generation with VAEs by using multi-scale Haar wavelet coefficients in the latent space. The method encodes image features into multi-scale detail and approximation coefficients and incorporates a learnable noise parameter for stochasticity. The reparameterization trick is reformulated, and the KL divergence term is addressed to enhance training. Wavelet sparsity principles are integrated into the objective function. Experimental evaluation on CIFAR-10 and other datasets shows that Wavelet-VAE produces higher visual fidelity and recovers finer details than conventional VAEs. The approach offers advantages for generative modeling but may have limitations that need to be explored further. Future research directions may focus on enhancing wavelet-based generative modeling techniques.

arXiv:2504.13214v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) are powerful generative models capable of learning compact latent representations. However, conventional VAEs often generate relatively blurry images due to their assumption of an isotropic Gaussian latent space and constraints in capturing high-frequency details. In this paper, we explore a novel wavelet-based approach (Wavelet-VAE) in which the latent space is constructed using multi-scale Haar wavelet coefficients. We propose a comprehensive method to encode the image features into multi-scale detail and approximation coefficients and introduce a learnable noise parameter to maintain stochasticity. We thoroughly discuss how to reformulate the reparameterization trick, address the KL divergence term, and integrate wavelet sparsity principles into the training objective. Our experimental evaluation on CIFAR-10 and other high-resolution datasets demonstrates that the Wavelet-VAE improves visual fidelity and recovers higher-resolution details compared to conventional VAEs. We conclude with a discussion of advantages, potential limitations, and future research directions for wavelet-based generative modeling.

item.title: SSTAF: Spatial-Spectral-Temporal Attention Fusion Transformer for Motor Imagery Classification
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Brain-computer interfaces, Electroencephalography, Motor imagery classification, Spatial-Spectral-Temporal Attention Fusion Transformer, Cross-subject classification models Summary: The paper introduces a Spatial-Spectral-Temporal Attention Fusion (SSTAF) Transformer for upper-limb motor imagery classification in EEG-based BCIs. The architecture includes spectral and spatial transformers, a transformer block, and a classifier network with attention mechanisms for feature discrimination. The model incorporates the short-time Fourier transform to extract time-frequency domain features. Evaluation on two datasets shows SSTAF Transformer outperforms traditional CNN-based models and existing transformer approaches, achieving accuracies of 76.83% and 68.30%. The novel transformer model addresses challenges of non-stationarity and inter-subject variability in EEG signals, providing a promising solution for neurorehabilitation and assistive technologies.

Summary:
arXiv:2504.13220v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Brain-computer interfaces (BCI) in electroencephalography (EEG)-based motor imagery classification offer promising solutions in neurorehabilitation and assistive technologies by enabling communication between the brain and external devices. However, the non-stationary nature of EEG signals and significant inter-subject variability cause substantial challenges for developing robust cross-subject classification models. This paper introduces a novel Spatial-Spectral-Temporal Attention Fusion (SSTAF) Transformer specifically designed for upper-limb motor imagery classification. Our architecture consists of a spectral transformer and a spatial transformer, followed by a transformer block and a classifier network. Each module is integrated with attention mechanisms that dynamically attend to the most discriminative patterns across multiple domains, such as spectral frequencies, spatial electrode locations, and temporal dynamics. The short-time Fourier transform is incorporated to extract features in the time-frequency domain to make it easier for the model to obtain a better feature distinction. We evaluated our SSTAF Transformer model on two publicly available datasets, the EEGMMIDB dataset, and BCI Competition IV-2a. SSTAF Transformer achieves an accuracy of 76.83% and 68.30% in the data sets, respectively, outperforms traditional CNN-based architectures and a few existing transformer-based approaches.

item.title: ICAS: IP Adapter and ControlNet-based Attention Structure for Multi-Subject Style Transfer Optimization
item.content:encoded:
Style transfer, multi-subject, images, ICAS, diffusion model
Summary: ICAS is a novel framework for efficient and controllable multi-subject style transfer in images. It uses IP-Adapter and ControlNet for adaptive style injection and structural conditioning, respectively, which helps in preserving global layout and accurate style synthesis. The framework fine-tunes only the content injection branch of a pre-trained diffusion model, ensuring identity-specific semantics while enhancing style controllability. Additionally, ICAS introduces a cyclic multi-subject content embedding mechanism for effective style transfer without the need for extensive stylized data. Experimental results demonstrate that ICAS outperforms existing methods in structure preservation, style consistency, and inference efficiency, making it a promising approach for multi-subject style transfer in real-world applications.
arXiv:2504.13224v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Generating multi-subject stylized images remains a significant challenge due to the ambiguity in defining style attributes (e.g., color, texture, atmosphere, and structure) and the difficulty in consistently applying them across multiple subjects. Although recent diffusion-based text-to-image models have achieved remarkable progress, existing methods typically rely on computationally expensive inversion procedures or large-scale stylized datasets. Moreover, these methods often struggle with maintaining multi-subject semantic fidelity and are limited by high inference costs. To address these limitations, we propose ICAS (IP-Adapter and ControlNet-based Attention Structure), a novel framework for efficient and controllable multi-subject style transfer. Instead of full-model tuning, ICAS adaptively fine-tunes only the content injection branch of a pre-trained diffusion model, thereby preserving identity-specific semantics while enhancing style controllability. By combining IP-Adapter for adaptive style injection with ControlNet for structural conditioning, our framework ensures faithful global layout preservation alongside accurate local style synthesis. Furthermore, ICAS introduces a cyclic multi-subject content embedding mechanism, which enables effective style transfer under limited-data settings without the need for extensive stylized corpora. Extensive experiments show that ICAS achieves superior performance in structure preservation, style consistency, and inference efficiency, establishing a new paradigm for multi-subject style transfer in real-world applications.

item.title: WildFireCan-MMD: A Multimodal dataset for Classification of User-generated Content During Wildfires in Canada
item.content:encoded:
Dataset, wildfires, social media, information access, multimodal

Summary: The study introduces WildFireCan-MMD, a new dataset containing posts from Canadian wildfires annotated across 13 themes. It addresses the need for rapid information access during wildfires by leveraging social media data. The research compares the performance of Vision Language Models and custom-trained classifiers on the dataset, demonstrating the superiority of trained models over zero-shot prompting. The findings emphasize the significance of tailored datasets and task-specific training in extracting relevant insights from social media. The study highlights the importance of localized datasets for disaster response, underscoring the variability in requirements across regions and contexts. Ultimately, the research showcases the effectiveness of simple trained models in surpassing zero-shot prompting when labeled data is available, outlining the value of investing in customized approaches for information extraction during emergencies.
arXiv:2504.13231v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Rapid information access is vital during wildfires, yet traditional data sources are slow and costly. Social media offers real-time updates, but extracting relevant insights remains a challenge. We present WildFireCan-MMD, a new multimodal dataset of X posts from recent Canadian wildfires, annotated across 13 key themes. Evaluating both Vision Language Models and custom-trained classifiers, we show that while zero-shot prompting offers quick deployment, even simple trained models outperform them when labelled data is available, by up to 23%. Our findings highlight the enduring importance of tailored datasets and task-specific training. Importantly, such datasets should be localized, as disaster response requirements vary across regions and contexts.

item.title: Dynamic Memory-enhanced Transformer for Hyperspectral Image Classification
item.content:encoded:
Proposed Keywords: Hyperspectral image classification, MemFormer, Memory-enhanced transformer, Spatial-spectral correlations, Benchmark datasets Summary: MemFormer is introduced as a lightweight and memory-enhanced transformer model for hyperspectral image (HSI) classification. It addresses the challenges of capturing fine-grained relationships in spatial-spectral correlations by incorporating a memory-enhanced multi-head attention mechanism. This mechanism refines a dynamic memory module iteratively to enhance feature extraction and reduce redundancy across layers. A dynamic memory enrichment strategy is employed to capture complex spatial and spectral dependencies for more expressive feature representations. To ensure structural consistency, a spatial-spectral positional encoding (SSPE) customized for HSI data is integrated. Experimental results on benchmark datasets show MemFormer outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in terms of classification accuracy. Overall, MemFormer demonstrates superior performance in HSI classification by effectively leveraging memory-enhanced attention mechanisms and dynamic memory enrichment strategies.

Summary:
arXiv:2504.13242v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Hyperspectral image (HSI) classification remains a challenging task due to the intricate spatial-spectral correlations. Existing transformer models excel in capturing long-range dependencies but often suffer from information redundancy and attention inefficiencies, limiting their ability to model fine-grained relationships crucial for HSI classification. To overcome these limitations, this work proposes MemFormer, a lightweight and memory-enhanced transformer. MemFormer introduces a memory-enhanced multi-head attention mechanism that iteratively refines a dynamic memory module, enhancing feature extraction while reducing redundancy across layers. Additionally, a dynamic memory enrichment strategy progressively captures complex spatial and spectral dependencies, leading to more expressive feature representations. To further improve structural consistency, we incorporate a spatial-spectral positional encoding (SSPE) tailored for HSI data, ensuring continuity without the computational burden of convolution-based approaches. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that MemFormer achieves superior classification accuracy, outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

item.title: ChartQA-X: Generating Explanations for Charts
item.content:encoded:
dataset, chart types, questions, answers, explanations Summary: ChartQA-X is a new dataset designed to help explain complex information in visual charts through answering questions. The dataset consists of various chart types and includes over 28,000 contextually relevant questions, answers, and detailed explanations. These explanations are generated by six different models, with the best responses chosen based on metrics like faithfulness, informativeness, coherence, and perplexity. Models fine-tuned on this dataset for explanation generation show improved performance across various metrics and demonstrate enhanced accuracy in question-answering tasks on new datasets. By integrating answers with explanatory narratives, this approach aims to enhance the effectiveness of intelligent agents in conveying complex information, improving user understanding, and building trust in the responses generated.

Summary:
arXiv:2504.13275v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The ability to interpret and explain complex information from visual data in charts is crucial for data-driven decision-making. In this work, we address the challenge of providing explanations alongside answering questions about chart images. We present ChartQA-X, a comprehensive dataset comprising various chart types with 28,299 contextually relevant questions, answers, and detailed explanations. These explanations are generated by prompting six different models and selecting the best responses based on metrics such as faithfulness, informativeness, coherence, and perplexity. Our experiments show that models fine-tuned on our dataset for explanation generation achieve superior performance across various metrics and demonstrate improved accuracy in question-answering tasks on new datasets. By integrating answers with explanatory narratives, our approach enhances the ability of intelligent agents to convey complex information effectively, improve user understanding, and foster trust in the generated responses.

item.title: LIFT+: Lightweight Fine-Tuning for Long-Tail Learning
item.content:encoded:
<div> Keywords: fine-tuning, long-tail learning, lightweight, consistent class distributions, LIFT+
Summary: - The study examines the impact of fine-tuning strategies on long-tail learning performance, revealing a need for improvement in efficiency and accuracy. - Heavy fine-tuning can negatively affect performance on tail classes, while lightweight fine-tuning proves more effective. - The phenomenon is attributed to inconsistent class conditional distributions induced by heavy fine-tuning. - LIFT+ is introduced as a lightweight fine-tuning framework that optimizes consistent class conditions and incorporates semantic-aware initialization, minimalist data augmentation, and test-time ensembling. - LIFT+ significantly reduces training epochs and learned parameters, outperforming existing approaches by a considerable margin. <div> arXiv:2504.13282v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The fine-tuning paradigm has emerged as a prominent approach for addressing long-tail learning tasks in the era of foundation models. However, the impact of fine-tuning strategies on long-tail learning performance remains unexplored. In this work, we disclose that existing paradigms exhibit a profound misuse of fine-tuning methods, leaving significant room for improvement in both efficiency and accuracy. Specifically, we reveal that heavy fine-tuning (fine-tuning a large proportion of model parameters) can lead to non-negligible performance deterioration on tail classes, whereas lightweight fine-tuning demonstrates superior effectiveness. Through comprehensive theoretical and empirical validation, we identify this phenomenon as stemming from inconsistent class conditional distributions induced by heavy fine-tuning. Building on this insight, we propose LIFT+, an innovative lightweight fine-tuning framework to optimize consistent class conditions. Furthermore, LIFT+ incorporates semantic-aware initialization, minimalist data augmentation, and test-time ensembling to enhance adaptation and generalization of foundation models. Our framework provides an efficient and accurate pipeline that facilitates fast convergence and model compactness. Extensive experiments demonstrate that LIFT+ significantly reduces both training epochs (from $\sim$100 to $\leq$15) and learned parameters (less than 1%), while surpassing state-of-the-art approaches by a considerable margin. The source code is available at https://github.com/shijxcs/LIFT-plus.

item.title: Weak Cube R-CNN: Weakly Supervised 3D Detection using only 2D Bounding Boxes
item.content:encoded:
monocular 3D object detection, weakly-supervised learning, 2D box annotations, weak Cube R-CNN, depth and orientation estimation Summary:
Monocular 3D object detection is crucial in computer vision, but requires costly 3D labeled data for training. This study introduces a weakly-supervised approach, Weak Cube R-CNN, that enables 3D object detection using only 2D box annotations. The method leverages pre-trained 2D models to estimate depth and orientation, using these estimates as pseudo-ground truths during training. By incorporating information from the 2D models into the loss functions, the model learns to predict 3D objects without explicit 3D annotations. Experimental results on the SUN RGB-D dataset demonstrate improved accuracy compared to a baseline method with equivalent annotation effort. While not as precise as methods using 3D labels, the weakly-supervised approach shows potential for reducing data requirements in 3D object detection tasks.

Summary:
arXiv:2504.13297v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Monocular 3D object detection is an essential task in computer vision, and it has several applications in robotics and virtual reality. However, 3D object detectors are typically trained in a fully supervised way, relying extensively on 3D labeled data, which is labor-intensive and costly to annotate. This work focuses on weakly-supervised 3D detection to reduce data needs using a monocular method that leverages a singlecamera system over expensive LiDAR sensors or multi-camera setups. We propose a general model Weak Cube R-CNN, which can predict objects in 3D at inference time, requiring only 2D box annotations for training by exploiting the relationship between 2D projections of 3D cubes. Our proposed method utilizes pre-trained frozen foundation 2D models to estimate depth and orientation information on a training set. We use these estimated values as pseudo-ground truths during training. We design loss functions that avoid 3D labels by incorporating information from the external models into the loss. In this way, we aim to implicitly transfer knowledge from these large foundation 2D models without having access to 3D bounding box annotations. Experimental results on the SUN RGB-D dataset show increased performance in accuracy compared to an annotation time equalized Cube R-CNN baseline. While not precise for centimetre-level measurements, this method provides a strong foundation for further research.

item.title: SAR Object Detection with Self-Supervised Pretraining and Curriculum-Aware Sampling
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Object detection, Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) imagery, Self-supervised learning, Vision transformer, Curriculum learning
Summary: TRANSAR is a novel self-supervised SAR object detection model that addresses challenges in detecting small objects in satellite-borne SAR images. The model incorporates masked image pre-training on a large unlabeled SAR dataset and utilizes binary semantic segmentation to isolate objects of interest from the background. An adaptive sampling scheduler adjusts the target class distribution during training to tackle class imbalance. By outperforming traditional supervised architectures and state-of-the-art self-supervised learning-based models, TRANSAR demonstrates superior performance on benchmark SAR datasets. The approach is designed to enhance object detection in SAR imagery for applications such as urban monitoring and disaster response, overcoming limitations posed by low spatial resolution and noise in SAR data. TRANSAR's innovative methodology showcases the potential of self-supervised vision transformers in advancing object detection capabilities in satellite-based SAR applications.

Summary:
arXiv:2504.13310v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Object detection in satellite-borne Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) imagery holds immense potential in tasks such as urban monitoring and disaster response. However, the inherent complexities of SAR data and the scarcity of annotations present significant challenges in the advancement of object detection in this domain. Notably, the detection of small objects in satellite-borne SAR images poses a particularly intricate problem, because of the technology's relatively low spatial resolution and inherent noise. Furthermore, the lack of large labelled SAR datasets hinders the development of supervised deep learning-based object detection models. In this paper, we introduce TRANSAR, a novel self-supervised end-to-end vision transformer-based SAR object detection model that incorporates masked image pre-training on an unlabeled SAR image dataset that spans more than $25,700$ km\textsuperscript{2} ground area. Unlike traditional object detection formulation, our approach capitalises on auxiliary binary semantic segmentation, designed to segregate objects of interest during the post-tuning, especially the smaller ones, from the background. In addition, to address the innate class imbalance due to the disproportion of the object to the image size, we introduce an adaptive sampling scheduler that dynamically adjusts the target class distribution during training based on curriculum learning and model feedback. This approach allows us to outperform conventional supervised architecture such as DeepLabv3 or UNet, and state-of-the-art self-supervised learning-based arhitectures such as DPT, SegFormer or UperNet, as shown by extensive evaluations on benchmark SAR datasets.

item.title: VLLFL: A Vision-Language Model Based Lightweight Federated Learning Framework for Smart Agriculture
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: object detection, smart agriculture, federated learning, privacy-preserving, vision-language model Summary: VLLFL is introduced as a lightweight federated learning framework for object detection in smart agriculture. It utilizes a vision-language model (VLM) to enhance detection accuracy while maintaining privacy. By training a compact prompt generator, VLLFL improves VLM performance by 14.53% and reduces communication overhead by 99.3%. The framework is specifically designed to address privacy concerns related to sensitive agricultural data spread across multiple farms. VLLFL is capable of identifying crop health, pest infestations, optimizing harvesting processes, and detecting harmful animals in agriculture. Overall, it offers an efficient, scalable, and privacy-preserving solution tailored for agricultural applications.

Summary:
arXiv:2504.13365v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: In modern smart agriculture, object detection plays a crucial role by enabling automation, precision farming, and monitoring of resources. From identifying crop health and pest infestations to optimizing harvesting processes, accurate object detection enhances both productivity and sustainability. However, training object detection models often requires large-scale data collection and raises privacy concerns, particularly when sensitive agricultural data is distributed across farms. To address these challenges, we propose VLLFL, a vision-language model-based lightweight federated learning framework (VLLFL). It harnesses the generalization and context-aware detection capabilities of the vision-language model (VLM) and leverages the privacy-preserving nature of federated learning. By training a compact prompt generator to boost the performance of the VLM deployed across different farms, VLLFL preserves privacy while reducing communication overhead. Experimental results demonstrate that VLLFL achieves 14.53% improvement in the performance of VLM while reducing 99.3% communication overhead. Spanning tasks from identifying a wide variety of fruits to detecting harmful animals in agriculture, the proposed framework offers an efficient, scalable, and privacy-preserving solution specifically tailored to agricultural applications.

item.title: POET: Supporting Prompting Creativity and Personalization with Automated Expansion of Text-to-Image Generation
item.content:encoded:
discover, text-to-image, generative models, interactive tool, personalization Summary: POET is an interactive tool designed to assist users in the early creative ideation stages by automatically discovering dimensions of homogeneity in text-to-image generative models. It then expands these dimensions to diversify the output space of generated images and learns from user feedback to personalize expansions. The tool aims to provide users with novel and high-quality images that adhere to their specifications, assisting in creative exploration. An evaluation with 28 users across different creative task domains showed that POET generated results with higher perceived diversity and helped users reach satisfaction in fewer prompts. This enabled users to deliberate and reflect on a wider range of possible results during the co-creative process. By focusing on visual creativity, POET demonstrates how future text-to-image generation tools can support diverse user needs and values during the ideation stages of their work.

Summary:
arXiv:2504.13392v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: State-of-the-art visual generative AI tools hold immense potential to assist users in the early ideation stages of creative tasks -- offering the ability to generate (rather than search for) novel and unprecedented (instead of existing) images of considerable quality that also adhere to boundless combinations of user specifications. However, many large-scale text-to-image systems are designed for broad applicability, yielding conventional output that may limit creative exploration. They also employ interaction methods that may be difficult for beginners. Given that creative end users often operate in diverse, context-specific ways that are often unpredictable, more variation and personalization are necessary. We introduce POET, a real-time interactive tool that (1) automatically discovers dimensions of homogeneity in text-to-image generative models, (2) expands these dimensions to diversify the output space of generated images, and (3) learns from user feedback to personalize expansions. An evaluation with 28 users spanning four creative task domains demonstrated POET's ability to generate results with higher perceived diversity and help users reach satisfaction in fewer prompts during creative tasks, thereby prompting them to deliberate and reflect more on a wider range of possible produced results during the co-creative process. Focusing on visual creativity, POET offers a first glimpse of how interaction techniques of future text-to-image generation tools may support and align with more pluralistic values and the needs of end users during the ideation stages of their work.

item.title: BeetleVerse: A study on taxonomic classification of ground beetles
item.content:encoded:
<div> beetles, vision models, taxonomic classification, sample efficiency, domain adaptation Summary: - The study evaluates 12 vision models for taxonomic classification of ground beetles across diverse datasets. - The best performing model achieved 97% accuracy at the genus level and 94% at the species level. - Sample efficiency analysis showed potential for reducing train data requirements by up to 50% with minimal performance impact. - Domain adaptation experiments highlighted significant challenges in transferring models from lab to in-situ images, indicating a critical domain gap. - The research lays a foundation for automated taxonomic classification of beetles, while also advancing sample-efficient learning and cross-domain adaptation for diverse ecological datasets.
Summary: <div> arXiv:2504.13393v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Ground beetles are a highly sensitive and speciose biological indicator, making them vital for monitoring biodiversity. However, they are currently an underutilized resource due to the manual effort required by taxonomic experts to perform challenging species differentiations based on subtle morphological differences, precluding widespread applications. In this paper, we evaluate 12 vision models on taxonomic classification across four diverse, long-tailed datasets spanning over 230 genera and 1769 species, with images ranging from controlled laboratory settings to challenging field-collected (in-situ) photographs. We further explore taxonomic classification in two important real-world contexts: sample efficiency and domain adaptation. Our results show that the Vision and Language Transformer combined with an MLP head is the best performing model, with 97\% accuracy at genus and 94\% at species level. Sample efficiency analysis shows that we can reduce train data requirements by up to 50\% with minimal compromise in performance. The domain adaptation experiments reveal significant challenges when transferring models from lab to in-situ images, highlighting a critical domain gap. Overall, our study lays a foundation for large-scale automated taxonomic classification of beetles, and beyond that, advances sample-efficient learning and cross-domain adaptation for diverse long-tailed ecological datasets.

item.title: Towards a Multi-Agent Vision-Language System for Zero-Shot Novel Hazardous Object Detection for Autonomous Driving Safety
item.content:encoded:
<div> Keywords: autonomous driving, hazard detection, vision-language reasoning, zero-shot object detection, anomaly detection
Summary: Anomalies in visual data pose a significant challenge in autonomous driving, particularly in video streams. Existing models struggle with out-of-label hazards due to predefined object categories. A novel multimodal approach integrating vision-language reasoning and zero-shot object detection is proposed to enhance hazard identification. The pipeline includes a Vision-Language Model (VLM) and a Large Language Model (LLM) for detecting hazardous objects in traffic scenes. OpenAI's CLIP model is integrated to refine object detection and improve localization accuracy. A ground truth dataset is created by extending the COOOL anomaly detection benchmark dataset with natural language descriptions for hazard annotations. Model performance is evaluated based on semantic similarity between predicted hazard descriptions and ground truth annotations using cosine similarity. Tools for structuring and managing large-scale hazard detection datasets are also released. The study sheds light on the strengths and limitations of current vision-language-based approaches, providing insights for future enhancements in autonomous hazard detection systems. <div> arXiv:2504.13399v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Detecting anomalous hazards in visual data, particularly in video streams, is a critical challenge in autonomous driving. Existing models often struggle with unpredictable, out-of-label hazards due to their reliance on predefined object categories. In this paper, we propose a multimodal approach that integrates vision-language reasoning with zero-shot object detection to improve hazard identification and explanation. Our pipeline consists of a Vision-Language Model (VLM), a Large Language Model (LLM), in order to detect hazardous objects within a traffic scene. We refine object detection by incorporating OpenAI's CLIP model to match predicted hazards with bounding box annotations, improving localization accuracy. To assess model performance, we create a ground truth dataset by denoising and extending the foundational COOOL (Challenge-of-Out-of-Label) anomaly detection benchmark dataset with complete natural language descriptions for hazard annotations. We define a means of hazard detection and labeling evaluation on the extended dataset using cosine similarity. This evaluation considers the semantic similarity between the predicted hazard description and the annotated ground truth for each video. Additionally, we release a set of tools for structuring and managing large-scale hazard detection datasets. Our findings highlight the strengths and limitations of current vision-language-based approaches, offering insights into future improvements in autonomous hazard detection systems. Our models, scripts, and data can be found at https://github.com/mi3labucm/COOOLER.git

item.title: CytoFM: The first cytology foundation model
item.content:encoded:
Cytology, cancer diagnostics, deep learning models, CytoFM, self-supervised foundation model

Summary: Cytology plays a crucial role in cancer diagnostics, but developing deep learning models for digital cytology faces challenges due to sample heterogeneity. The CytoFM model is introduced as the first cytology self-supervised foundation model, pre-trained on diverse cytology datasets using the iBOT framework. Evaluation on breast cancer classification and cell type identification tasks shows CytoFM outperforms existing foundation models. Visualizations indicate CytoFM attends to cytologically relevant features, showcasing its ability to learn robust and generalizable representations from cytology data despite a small pre-training dataset.
arXiv:2504.13402v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Cytology is essential for cancer diagnostics and screening due to its minimally invasive nature. However, the development of robust deep learning models for digital cytology is challenging due to the heterogeneity in staining and preparation methods of samples, differences across organs, and the limited availability of large, diverse, annotated datasets. Developing a task-specific model for every cytology application is impractical and non-cytology-specific foundation models struggle to generalize to tasks in this domain where the emphasis is on cell morphology. To address these challenges, we introduce CytoFM, the first cytology self-supervised foundation model. Using iBOT, a self-supervised Vision Transformer (ViT) training framework incorporating masked image modeling and self-distillation, we pretrain CytoFM on a diverse collection of cytology datasets to learn robust, transferable representations. We evaluate CytoFM on multiple downstream cytology tasks, including breast cancer classification and cell type identification, using an attention-based multiple instance learning framework. Our results demonstrate that CytoFM performs better on two out of three downstream tasks than existing foundation models pretrained on histopathology (UNI) or natural images (iBOT-Imagenet). Visualizations of learned representations demonstrate our model is able to attend to cytologically relevant features. Despite a small pre-training dataset, CytoFM's promising results highlight the ability of task-agnostic pre-training approaches to learn robust and generalizable features from cytology data.

item.title: ProgRoCC: A Progressive Approach to Rough Crowd Counting
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Crowd Counting, Estimation, CLIP, Progressive Learning, Vision-Language Matching
Summary: Rough Crowd Counting is proposed as a more feasible and accurate approach for estimating crowd sizes by using rough annotations instead of per-target annotations. The ProgRoCC method, based on CLIP, employs a progressive estimation learning strategy that delivers quick and superior results in semi- and weakly-supervised crowd counting. A vision-language matching adapter is introduced to optimize key-value pairs and refine visual features through effective matches of two modalities. The approach outperforms existing methods on three popular crowd counting datasets, showcasing its effectiveness in accurately estimating crowd sizes in images.

Summary:
arXiv:2504.13405v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: As the number of individuals in a crowd grows, enumeration-based techniques become increasingly infeasible and their estimates increasingly unreliable. We propose instead an estimation-based version of the problem: we label Rough Crowd Counting that delivers better accuracy on the basis of training data that is easier to acquire. Rough crowd counting requires only rough annotations of the number of targets in an image, instead of the more traditional, and far more expensive, per-target annotations. We propose an approach to the rough crowd counting problem based on CLIP, termed ProgRoCC. Specifically, we introduce a progressive estimation learning strategy that determines the object count through a coarse-to-fine approach. This approach delivers answers quickly, outperforms the state-of-the-art in semi- and weakly-supervised crowd counting. In addition, we design a vision-language matching adapter that optimizes key-value pairs by mining effective matches of two modalities to refine the visual features, thereby improving the final performance. Extensive experimental results on three widely adopted crowd counting datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our method.

item.title: LoRA-Based Continual Learning with Constraints on Critical Parameter Changes
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: LoRA-based continual learning, Vision Transformer, orthogonal LoRA tuning, freezing critical parameters, orthogonal LoRA composition Summary: This study introduces a novel approach to enhance continual learning by combining LoRA-based methods with freezing critical parameters in Vision Transformer (ViT) models. The proposed method, named orthogonal LoRA composition (LoRAC), utilizes QR decomposition to improve plasticity and mitigate forgetting in pre-trained models. Through extensive experiments and comparisons, the effectiveness of the method is validated, showcasing state-of-the-art performance on various continual learning benchmarks. Specifically, on the Split CIFAR-100 dataset, the method achieves a significant accuracy improvement of 6.35% and reduces forgetting by 3.24% compared to existing techniques. The code for the proposed method is openly available on GitHub for further exploration and application.

Summary:
arXiv:2504.13407v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: LoRA-based continual learning represents a promising avenue for leveraging pre-trained models in downstream continual learning tasks. Recent studies have shown that orthogonal LoRA tuning effectively mitigates forgetting. However, this work unveils that under orthogonal LoRA tuning, the critical parameters for pre-tasks still change notably after learning post-tasks. To address this problem, we directly propose freezing the most critical parameter matrices in the Vision Transformer (ViT) for pre-tasks before learning post-tasks. In addition, building on orthogonal LoRA tuning, we propose orthogonal LoRA composition (LoRAC) based on QR decomposition, which may further enhance the plasticity of our method. Elaborate ablation studies and extensive comparisons demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed method. Our results indicate that our method achieves state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance on several well-known continual learning benchmarks. For instance, on the Split CIFAR-100 dataset, our method shows a 6.35\% improvement in accuracy and a 3.24\% reduction in forgetting compared to previous methods. Our code is available at https://github.com/learninginvision/LoRAC-IPC.

item.title: How Learnable Grids Recover Fine Detail in Low Dimensions: A Neural Tangent Kernel Analysis of Multigrid Parametric Encodings
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: neural networks, Fourier feature encodings, multigrid parametric encodings, spectral bias, NTK Summary: Neural networks commonly used in computer graphics and scientific computing struggle to learn high frequency information due to spectral bias. Fourier feature encodings (FFE) and multigrid parametric encodings (MPE) are two techniques to mitigate this issue. While FFE is the standard, MPE often outperforms it by learning representations with higher resolution and finer detail. The analysis using the neural tangent kernel (NTK) shows that MPE improves performance through its grid structure, not just the learned embedding, unlike FFE. Empirical validation on image and 3D surface regression tasks demonstrates MPE's significant improvement in performance metrics such as PSNR and MS-SSIM. MPE increases the minimum eigenvalue by 8 orders of magnitude over the baseline, resulting in a substantial increase in image quality metrics compared to FFE and baseline methods.

Summary:
arXiv:2504.13412v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Neural networks that map between low dimensional spaces are ubiquitous in computer graphics and scientific computing; however, in their naive implementation, they are unable to learn high frequency information. We present a comprehensive analysis comparing the two most common techniques for mitigating this spectral bias: Fourier feature encodings (FFE) and multigrid parametric encodings (MPE). FFEs are seen as the standard for low dimensional mappings, but MPEs often outperform them and learn representations with higher resolution and finer detail. FFE's roots in the Fourier transform, make it susceptible to aliasing if pushed too far, while MPEs, which use a learned grid structure, have no such limitation. To understand the difference in performance, we use the neural tangent kernel (NTK) to evaluate these encodings through the lens of an analogous kernel regression. By finding a lower bound on the smallest eigenvalue of the NTK, we prove that MPEs improve a network's performance through the structure of their grid and not their learnable embedding. This mechanism is fundamentally different from FFEs, which rely solely on their embedding space to improve performance. Results are empirically validated on a 2D image regression task using images taken from 100 synonym sets of ImageNet and 3D implicit surface regression on objects from the Stanford graphics dataset. Using peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) and multiscale structural similarity (MS-SSIM) to evaluate how well fine details are learned, we show that the MPE increases the minimum eigenvalue by 8 orders of magnitude over the baseline and 2 orders of magnitude over the FFE. The increase in spectrum corresponds to a 15 dB (PSNR) / 0.65 (MS-SSIM) increase over baseline and a 12 dB (PSNR) / 0.33 (MS-SSIM) increase over the FFE.

item.title: Mono3R: Exploiting Monocular Cues for Geometric 3D Reconstruction
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: data-driven, geometric multi-view 3D reconstruction, monocular geometry estimation, matching-based methods, robustness Summary:
Recent advancements in data-driven geometric multi-view 3D reconstruction models, such as DUSt3R, have demonstrated exceptional performance in 3D vision tasks with the help of large-scale 3D datasets. However, existing models face challenges in areas with limited matching cues, like weakly textured regions and low-light conditions, resulting in degraded reconstruction quality. To address this, a monocular-guided refinement module is proposed to enhance multi-view reconstruction frameworks by integrating monocular geometric priors. This integration improves the robustness of reconstruction systems, leading to high-quality reconstructions. Through extensive experiments on various benchmarks, the method shows significant enhancements in multi-view camera pose estimation and point cloud accuracy.
arXiv:2504.13419v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent advances in data-driven geometric multi-view 3D reconstruction foundation models (e.g., DUSt3R) have shown remarkable performance across various 3D vision tasks, facilitated by the release of large-scale, high-quality 3D datasets. However, as we observed, constrained by their matching-based principles, the reconstruction quality of existing models suffers significant degradation in challenging regions with limited matching cues, particularly in weakly textured areas and low-light conditions. To mitigate these limitations, we propose to harness the inherent robustness of monocular geometry estimation to compensate for the inherent shortcomings of matching-based methods. Specifically, we introduce a monocular-guided refinement module that integrates monocular geometric priors into multi-view reconstruction frameworks. This integration substantially enhances the robustness of multi-view reconstruction systems, leading to high-quality feed-forward reconstructions. Comprehensive experiments across multiple benchmarks demonstrate that our method achieves substantial improvements in both mutli-view camera pose estimation and point cloud accuracy.

item.title: HSACNet: Hierarchical Scale-Aware Consistency Regularized Semi-Supervised Change Detection
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Semi-supervised change detection, Hierarchical Scale-Aware Consistency regularized Network, Segment Anything Model 2, Scale-Aware Differential Attention Module, dual-augmentation consistency regularization Summary: HSACNet is a novel Hierarchical Scale-Aware Consistency regularized Network designed for Semi-supervised change detection (SSCD) in remote sensing images. Using SAM2 as the encoder, HSACNet extracts inter-layer multi-scale features and applies adapters for efficient fine-tuning. The Scale-Aware Differential Attention Module (SADAM) accurately captures intra-layer multi-scale change features while suppressing noise, enhancing change detection performance. The network also incorporates a dual-augmentation consistency regularization strategy to effectively utilize unlabeled data. Experimental results on four change detection benchmarks demonstrate that HSACNet achieves state-of-the-art performance with reduced parameters and computational cost. This innovative approach addresses the limitations of existing methods, particularly in complex scenarios with noisy data, making it a promising solution for SSCD tasks.

Summary:
HSACNet integrates SAM2 for inter-layer multi-scale feature extraction, utilizes SADAM to capture intra-layer multi-scale change features, incorporates dual-augmentation consistency regularization, and achieves state-of-the-art performance in SSCD tasks with reduced parameters and computational cost.
arXiv:2504.13428v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Semi-supervised change detection (SSCD) aims to detect changes between bi-temporal remote sensing images by utilizing limited labeled data and abundant unlabeled data. Existing methods struggle in complex scenarios, exhibiting poor performance when confronted with noisy data. They typically neglect intra-layer multi-scale features while emphasizing inter-layer fusion, harming the integrity of change objects with different scales. In this paper, we propose HSACNet, a Hierarchical Scale-Aware Consistency regularized Network for SSCD. Specifically, we integrate Segment Anything Model 2 (SAM2), using its Hiera backbone as the encoder to extract inter-layer multi-scale features and applying adapters for parameter-efficient fine-tuning. Moreover, we design a Scale-Aware Differential Attention Module (SADAM) that can precisely capture intra-layer multi-scale change features and suppress noise. Additionally, a dual-augmentation consistency regularization strategy is adopted to effectively utilize the unlabeled data. Extensive experiments across four CD benchmarks demonstrate that our HSACNet achieves state-of-the-art performance, with reduced parameters and computational cost.

item.title: Circular Image Deturbulence using Quasi-conformal Geometry
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: inhomogeneous media, image restoration, unsupervised approach, quasi-conformal geometry, tight-frame blocks Summary: The paper introduces the Circular Quasi-Conformal Deturbulence (CQCD) framework for removing image distortions caused by inhomogeneous media. This unsupervised approach employs a circular architecture to ensure geometric accuracy and visual fidelity in restored images. By leveraging computational quasi-conformal geometry theories, the framework regularizes the mapping process to maintain structural integrity and prevent artifacts. The use of tight-frame blocks aids in encoding distortion-sensitive features for precise image recovery. Experimental evaluations on synthetic and real-world images show that CQCD surpasses existing deturbulence methods in terms of image restoration quality and accuracy in deformation field estimations.

Summary: The CQCD framework offers a novel solution for image restoration in the presence of inhomogeneous media, showcasing superior performance compared to current state-of-the-art methods. Through its circular architecture and computational techniques, CQCD ensures accurate and visually faithful image restoration while preserving structural integrity and preventing unwanted artifacts. The integration of tight-frame blocks further enhances the precision of image recovery, making the framework a promising approach for addressing image distortions in various environments.
arXiv:2504.13432v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The presence of inhomogeneous media between optical sensors and objects leads to distorted imaging outputs, significantly complicating downstream image-processing tasks. A key challenge in image restoration is the lack of high-quality, paired-label images required for training supervised models. In this paper, we introduce the Circular Quasi-Conformal Deturbulence (CQCD) framework, an unsupervised approach for removing image distortions through a circular architecture. This design ensures that the restored image remains both geometrically accurate and visually faithful while preventing the accumulation of incorrect estimations.The circular restoration process involves both forward and inverse mapping. To ensure the bijectivity of the estimated non-rigid deformations, computational quasi-conformal geometry theories are leveraged to regularize the mapping, enforcing its homeomorphic properties. This guarantees a well-defined transformation that preserves structural integrity and prevents unwanted artifacts. Furthermore, tight-frame blocks are integrated to encode distortion-sensitive features for precise recovery. To validate the performance of our approach, we conduct evaluations on various synthetic and real-world captured images. Experimental results demonstrate that CQCD not only outperforms existing state-of-the-art deturbulence methods in terms of image restoration quality but also provides highly accurate deformation field estimations.

item.title: Temporal Propagation of Asymmetric Feature Pyramid for Surgical Scene Segmentation
item.content:encoded:
<div> segmentation, robot-assisted surgery, temporal feature propagation, attention architecture, video analysis
Summary: The paper introduces a new method for surgical scene segmentation in robot-assisted laparoscopic surgery. Existing approaches face challenges with static images and dynamic video complexities. The proposed method, called temporal asymmetric feature propagation network, addresses both issues by integrating temporal dependencies in surgical video streams. It includes a temporal query propagator and an aggregated asymmetric feature pyramid module to enhance feature representation and preserve discriminative features for anatomical structures and surgical instruments. The method outperforms current state-of-the-art methods on two public benchmarks, EndoVis2018 and Endoscapes2023, with significant improvements in mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) and mean Average Precision (mAP). The code will be made publicly available after the paper is accepted. <div> arXiv:2504.13440v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Surgical scene segmentation is crucial for robot-assisted laparoscopic surgery understanding. Current approaches face two challenges: (i) static image limitations including ambiguous local feature similarities and fine-grained structural details, and (ii) dynamic video complexities arising from rapid instrument motion and persistent visual occlusions. While existing methods mainly focus on spatial feature extraction, they fundamentally overlook temporal dependencies in surgical video streams. To address this, we present temporal asymmetric feature propagation network, a bidirectional attention architecture enabling cross-frame feature propagation. The proposed method contains a temporal query propagator that integrates multi-directional consistency constraints to enhance frame-specific feature representation, and an aggregated asymmetric feature pyramid module that preserves discriminative features for anatomical structures and surgical instruments. Our framework uniquely enables both temporal guidance and contextual reasoning for surgical scene understanding. Comprehensive evaluations on two public benchmarks show the proposed method outperforms the current SOTA methods by a large margin, with +16.4\% mIoU on EndoVis2018 and +3.3\% mAP on Endoscapes2023. The code will be publicly available after paper acceptance.

item.title: SatelliteCalculator: A Multi-Task Vision Foundation Model for Quantitative Remote Sensing Inversion
item.content:encoded:
model, remote sensing, ecological indicators, satellite, vision foundation

Quantitative remote sensing inversion is crucial for environmental monitoring by estimating ecological variables like vegetation indices and carbon stock. Existing vision foundation models focus on classification and segmentation, but their use in regression for remote sensing is limited. The multi-spectral and geospatial complexity of remote sensing data presents challenges for generalization. SatelliteCalculator is introduced as the first model designed for quantitative remote sensing inversion. It creates a dataset of over one million samples for eight ecological indicators, using physically defined index formulas. The model combines a Swin Transformer backbone with a prompt-guided architecture, including cross-attentive adapters and task-specific decoders. Experimental results on the Open-Canopy benchmark show that SatelliteCalculator achieves accurate results with reduced inference cost, demonstrating the potential for foundation models in remote sensing estimation and providing a scalable framework for task-specific applications.

Summary:
arXiv:2504.13442v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Quantitative remote sensing inversion plays a critical role in environmental monitoring, enabling the estimation of key ecological variables such as vegetation indices, canopy structure, and carbon stock. Although vision foundation models have achieved remarkable progress in classification and segmentation tasks, their application to physically interpretable regression remains largely unexplored. Furthermore, the multi-spectral nature and geospatial heterogeneity of remote sensing data pose significant challenges for generalization and transferability. To address these issues, we introduce SatelliteCalculator, the first vision foundation model tailored for quantitative remote sensing inversion. By leveraging physically defined index formulas, we automatically construct a large-scale dataset of over one million paired samples across eight core ecological indicators. The model integrates a frozen Swin Transformer backbone with a prompt-guided architecture, featuring cross-attentive adapters and lightweight task-specific MLP decoders. Experiments on the Open-Canopy benchmark demonstrate that SatelliteCalculator achieves competitive accuracy across all tasks while significantly reducing inference cost. Our results validate the feasibility of applying foundation models to quantitative inversion, and provide a scalable framework for task-adaptive remote sensing estimation.

item.title: MicroFlow: Domain-Specific Optical Flow for Ground Deformation Estimation in Seismic Events
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: ground displacement, deep learning, optical flow, sub-pixel precision, Total Variation regularization Summary: Ground displacement measurements are essential for geological studies but are challenging to collect directly. Traditional methods use optical satellite images and patch matching techniques for estimating displacement fields. However, deep learning-based optical flow models face challenges such as the lack of real ground truth and the need for sub-pixel precision. A novel deep learning model proposed in this study utilizes iterative refinement with explicit warping layers and a correlation-independent backbone to achieve sub-pixel precision. A non-convex variant of Total Variation regularization is also employed to preserve sharpness in fault lines while maintaining smoothness elsewhere. The model outperformed conventional geophysics methods on semi-synthetic benchmarks and demonstrated good generalization to real-world scenarios captured by medium- and high-resolution sensors. This advancement addresses the limitations of existing methods and shows promise for improving ground deformation analysis in geological studies. Summary:

Ground displacement measurements are crucial for geological studies and are traditionally estimated using optical satellite images. Deep learning models face challenges in achieving sub-pixel precision due to the absence of real ground truth and temporal variations. A novel model proposed in this study incorporates iterative refinements with explicit warping layers and a correlation-independent backbone for enhanced accuracy. Additionally, a non-convex Total Variation regularization maintains fault-line sharpness while ensuring smoothness elsewhere. The model outperforms conventional geophysics methods on benchmarks and demonstrates good performance in real-world scenarios with different sensor resolutions. This approach addresses key challenges in ground deformation analysis, offering significant advancements for geological studies.
arXiv:2504.13452v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Dense ground displacement measurements are crucial for geological studies but are impractical to collect directly. Traditionally, displacement fields are estimated using patch matching on optical satellite images from different acquisition times. While deep learning-based optical flow models are promising, their adoption in ground deformation analysis is hindered by challenges such as the absence of real ground truth, the need for sub-pixel precision, and temporal variations due to geological or anthropogenic changes. In particular, we identify that deep learning models relying on explicit correlation layers struggle at estimating small displacements in real-world conditions. Instead, we propose a model that employs iterative refinements with explicit warping layers and a correlation-independent backbone, enabling sub-pixel precision. Additionally, a non-convex variant of Total Variation regularization preserves fault-line sharpness while maintaining smoothness elsewhere. Our model significantly outperforms widely used geophysics methods on semi-synthetic benchmarks and generalizes well to challenging real-world scenarios captured by both medium- and high-resolution sensors. Project page: https://jbertrand89.github.io/microflow/.

item.title: Neural Ganglion Sensors: Learning Task-specific Event Cameras Inspired by the Neural Circuit of the Human Retina
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: event cameras, neural ganglion sensors, spatio-temporal features, video interpolation, optical flow Summary: Neural Ganglion Sensors are introduced as an extension of traditional event cameras, inspired by the data-efficient spiking mechanism of neurons in the human eye. These sensors learn task-specific spatio-temporal retinal kernels (RGC "events"), akin to retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) in the human eye. Unlike conventional event cameras, Neural Ganglion Sensors leverage local spatial context when deciding which events to fire. The study evaluates these sensors on video interpolation and optical flow tasks, showing improved performance compared to regular event cameras with reduced event bandwidth. This biologically inspired sensing approach offers promise for edge devices and other low-power, real-time applications that require efficient, high-resolution visual streams.

Summary:
arXiv:2504.13457v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Inspired by the data-efficient spiking mechanism of neurons in the human eye, event cameras were created to achieve high temporal resolution with minimal power and bandwidth requirements by emitting asynchronous, per-pixel intensity changes rather than conventional fixed-frame rate images. Unlike retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) in the human eye, however, which integrate signals from multiple photoreceptors within a receptive field to extract spatio-temporal features, conventional event cameras do not leverage local spatial context when deciding which events to fire. Moreover, the eye contains around 20 different kinds of RGCs operating in parallel, each attuned to different features or conditions. Inspired by this biological design, we introduce Neural Ganglion Sensors, an extension of traditional event cameras that learns task-specific spatio-temporal retinal kernels (i.e., RGC "events"). We evaluate our design on two challenging tasks: video interpolation and optical flow. Our results demonstrate that our biologically inspired sensing improves performance relative to conventional event cameras while reducing overall event bandwidth. These findings highlight the promise of RGC-inspired event sensors for edge devices and other low-power, real-time applications requiring efficient, high-resolution visual streams.

item.title: Learning from Noisy Pseudo-labels for All-Weather Land Cover Mapping
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: SAR image segmentation, semi-supervised learning, image resolution alignment, pseudo-labels, symmetric cross-entropy loss Summary: In the field of remote sensing, the segmentation of Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) images is challenging due to noise and lack of detailed information. Previous methods have used pseudo-labels generated from paired optical-SAR images, but these labels often contain noise leading to suboptimal results. A new method introduced in this study combines semi-supervised learning with image resolution alignment augmentation to generate more precise pseudo-labels. A symmetric cross-entropy loss function is also employed to reduce the impact of noisy labels. Additionally, a combination of training and testing techniques are used to improve land-cover mapping results. The proposed method achieved first place in the GRSS data fusion contest, showcasing its effectiveness in SAR image segmentation tasks. The code for the method is available on GitHub for further exploration.

Summary:
arXiv:2504.13458v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Semantic segmentation of SAR images has garnered significant attention in remote sensing due to the immunity of SAR sensors to cloudy weather and light conditions. Nevertheless, SAR imagery lacks detailed information and is plagued by significant speckle noise, rendering the annotation or segmentation of SAR images a formidable task. Recent efforts have resorted to annotating paired optical-SAR images to generate pseudo-labels through the utilization of an optical image segmentation network. However, these pseudo-labels are laden with noise, leading to suboptimal performance in SAR image segmentation. In this study, we introduce a more precise method for generating pseudo-labels by incorporating semi-supervised learning alongside a novel image resolution alignment augmentation. Furthermore, we introduce a symmetric cross-entropy loss to mitigate the impact of noisy pseudo-labels. Additionally, a bag of training and testing tricks is utilized to generate better land-cover mapping results. Our experiments on the GRSS data fusion contest indicate the effectiveness of the proposed method, which achieves first place. The code is available at https://github.com/StuLiu/DFC2025Track1.git.

item.title: Chain-of-Thought Textual Reasoning for Few-shot Temporal Action Localization
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: few-shot learning, temporal action localization, textual information, Chain-of-Thought reasoning, human anomaly detection
Summary:
This paper introduces a new few-shot temporal action localization method that incorporates textual information for improved performance. The proposed method utilizes Chain-of-Thought reasoning to leverage semantic information and enhance the model's ability to capture action commonalities and variations. A semantic-aware text-visual alignment module aligns query and support videos, while a Chain of Thought reasoning method guides the Vision Language Model and Large Language Model to generate CoT-like text descriptions for videos, capturing more variance of action than visual features. The method is evaluated on ActivityNet1.3 and THUMOS14 datasets and a new dataset named Human-related Anomaly Localization. Experimental results show significant improvements in single-instance and multi-instance scenarios. The code, data, and benchmark will be released for further research.
Summary:
arXiv:2504.13460v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Traditional temporal action localization (TAL) methods rely on large amounts of detailed annotated data, whereas few-shot TAL reduces this dependence by using only a few training samples to identify unseen action categories. However, existing few-shot TAL methods typically focus solely on video-level information, neglecting textual information, which can provide valuable semantic support for the localization task. Therefore, we propose a new few-shot temporal action localization method by Chain-of-Thought textual reasoning to improve localization performance. Specifically, we design a novel few-shot learning framework that leverages textual semantic information to enhance the model's ability to capture action commonalities and variations, which includes a semantic-aware text-visual alignment module designed to align the query and support videos at different levels. Meanwhile, to better express the temporal dependencies and causal relationships between actions at the textual level to assist action localization, we design a Chain of Thought (CoT)-like reasoning method that progressively guides the Vision Language Model (VLM) and Large Language Model (LLM) to generate CoT-like text descriptions for videos. The generated texts can capture more variance of action than visual features. We conduct extensive experiments on the publicly available ActivityNet1.3 and THUMOS14 datasets. We introduce the first dataset named Human-related Anomaly Localization and explore the application of the TAL task in human anomaly detection. The experimental results demonstrate that our proposed method significantly outperforms existing methods in single-instance and multi-instance scenarios. We will release our code, data and benchmark.

item.title: HMPE:HeatMap Embedding for Efficient Transformer-Based Small Object Detection
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Current Transformer-based methods, HeatMap Position Embedding, Multi-Scale ObjectBox-Heatmap Fusion Encoder, HeatMap Induced High-Quality Queries, small object detection Summary: HeatMap Position Embedding (HMPE) is introduced as a novel Transformer Optimization technique that enhances small object detection performance by integrating positional encoding with semantic detection information. The method includes innovative visualization for parameter fine-tuning. The Multi-Scale ObjectBox-Heatmap Fusion Encoder (MOHFE) and HeatMap Induced High-Quality Queries for Decoder (HIDQ) modules are created to generate high-quality queries and reduce background noise queries. By employing both heatmap embedding and Linear-Snake Conv(LSConv) feature engineering, the embedding of diverse small object categories is enhanced and decoder layers are reduced, leading to improved inference and training efficiency. In generalization experiments, the approach outperformed the baseline mAP on both small object and general datasets. The use of HMPE-enhanced embedding also significantly reduces the number of decoder layers, decreasing both inference and training costs.

Summary:
arXiv:2504.13469v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Current Transformer-based methods for small object detection continue emerging, yet they have still exhibited significant shortcomings. This paper introduces HeatMap Position Embedding (HMPE), a novel Transformer Optimization technique that enhances object detection performance by dynamically integrating positional encoding with semantic detection information through heatmap-guided adaptive learning.We also innovatively visualize the HMPE method, offering clear visualization of embedded information for parameter fine-tuning.We then create Multi-Scale ObjectBox-Heatmap Fusion Encoder (MOHFE) and HeatMap Induced High-Quality Queries for Decoder (HIDQ) modules. These are designed for the encoder and decoder, respectively, to generate high-quality queries and reduce background noise queries.Using both heatmap embedding and Linear-Snake Conv(LSConv) feature engineering, we enhance the embedding of massively diverse small object categories and reduced the decoder multihead layers, thereby accelerating both inference and training.In the generalization experiments, our approach outperforme the baseline mAP by 1.9% on the small object dataset (NWPU VHR-10) and by 1.2% on the general dataset (PASCAL VOC). By employing HMPE-enhanced embedding, we are able to reduce the number of decoder layers from eight to a minimum of three, significantly decreasing both inference and training costs.

item.title: Early Timestep Zero-Shot Candidate Selection for Instruction-Guided Image Editing
item.content:encoded:
diffusion models, image editing, seed selection, ELECT, background consistency
Summary:
